chapters.title: Rapidly evolving IoT malware EnemyBot now targeting Content Management System servers and Android devices

sentences.text: AT&T Alien Labs has been tracking a new IoT botnet dubbed EnemyBot, which is believed to be distributed by threat actor Keksec. During our investigations, Alien Labs has discovered that EnemyBot is expanding its capabilities, exploiting recently identified vulnerabilities (2022), and now targeting IoT devices, web servers, Android devices and content management system (CMS) servers. In addition, the malware base source code can now be found online on Github, making it widely accessible.
sentences.html: AT&T Alien Labs™ has been tracking a new IoT botnet dubbed “EnemyBot”, which is believed to be distributed by threat actor Keksec. During our investigations, Alien Labs has discovered that EnemyBot is expanding its capabilities, exploiting recently identified vulnerabilities (2022), and now targeting IoT devices, web servers, Android devices and content management system (CMS) servers. In addition, the malware base source code can now be found online on Github, making it widely accessible.

sentences.text: EnemyBots base source code can be found on Github, making it available to anyone who wants to leverage the malware in their attacks.<crlf>The malware is rapidly adopting one-day vulnerabilities as part of its exploitation capabilities.<crlf>Services such as VMware Workspace ONE, Adobe ColdFusion, WordPress, PHP Scriptcase and more are being targeted as well as IoT and Android devices.<crlf>The threat group behind EnemyBot, Keksec, is well-resourced and has the ability to update and add new capabilities to its arsenal of malware on a daily basis (see below for more detail on Keksec)
sentences.html:
• EnemyBot’s base source code can be found on Github, making it available to anyone who wants to leverage the malware in their attacks.
  • The malware is rapidly adopting one-day vulnerabilities as part of its exploitation capabilities.
  • Services such as VMware Workspace ONE, Adobe ColdFusion, WordPress, PHP Scriptcase and more are being targeted as well as IoT and Android devices.
  • The threat group behind EnemyBot, Keksec, is well-resourced and has the ability to update and add new capabilities to its arsenal of malware on a daily basis (see below for more detail on Keksec)

sentences.text: First discovered by Securonix in March 2022 and later detailed in an in-depth analysis by Fortinet, EnemyBot is a new malware distributed by the threat actor Keksec targeting Linux machines and IoT devices.
sentences.html: First discovered by Securonix in March 2022 and later detailed in an in-depth analysis by Fortinet, EnemyBot is a new malware distributed by the threat actor “Keksec” targeting Linux machines and IoT devices.

sentences.text: According to the malware Githubs repository, EnemyBot derives its source code from multiple botnets to a powerful and more adjustable malware. The original botnet code that EnemyBot is using includes: Mirai, Qbot, and Zbot. In addition, the malware includes custom development (see figure 1).
sentences.html: According to the malware Github’s repository, EnemyBot derives its source code from multiple botnets to a powerful and more adjustable malware. The original botnet code that EnemyBot is using includes: Mirai, Qbot, and Zbot. In addition, the malware includes custom development (see figure 1).

sentences.text: Figure 1. EnemyBot page on Github.
sentences.html: Figure 1. EnemyBot page on Github.

sentences.text: The Keksec threat group is reported to have formed back in 2016 by a number of experienced botnet actors. In November 2021, researchers from Qihoo 360 described in detail the threat actors activity in a presentation, attributing to the Keksec the development of botnets for different platforms including Windows and Linux:
sentences.html: The Keksec threat group is reported to have formed back in 2016 by a number of experienced botnet actors. In November 2021, researchers from Qihoo 360 described in detail the threat actor’s activity in a presentation, attributing to the Keksec the development of botnets for different platforms including Windows and Linux:

sentences.text: Linux based botnets: Tsunami and Gafgyt<crlf>Windows based botnets: DarkIRC, DarkHTTP<crlf>Dual systems: Necro (developed in Python)
sentences.html:
• Linux based botnets: Tsunami and Gafgyt
  • Windows based botnets: DarkIRC, DarkHTTP
  • Dual systems: Necro (developed in Python)

sentences.text: The developer of the Github page on EnemyBot self describes as a full time malware dev, that is also available for contract work. The individual states their workplace as Kek security, implying a potential relationship with the broader Keksec group (see figure 2).
sentences.html: The developer of the Github page on EnemyBot self describes as a “full time malware dev,” that is also available for contract work. The individual states their workplace as “Kek security,” implying a potential relationship with the broader Keksec group (see figure 2).

sentences.text: Figure 2. EnemyBot developer description.
sentences.html: Figure 2. EnemyBot developer description.

sentences.text: The malware repository on Github contains four main sections:
sentences.html: The malware repository on Github contains four main sections:

sentences.text: This module is a Python script file that downloads all dependencies and compiles the malware into different OS architectures including x86, ARM, macOS, OpenBSD, PowerPC, MIPS, and more (see figure 3)
sentences.html: This module is a Python script file that downloads all dependencies and compiles the malware into different OS architectures including x86, ARM, macOS, OpenBSD, PowerPC, MIPS, and more (see figure 3)

sentences.text: Figure 3. Compiling malware source code to macOS executable.
sentences.html: Figure 3. Compiling malware source code to macOS executable.

sentences.text: Once compilation is complete, the script then creates a batch file update.sh which is used by the bot as a downloader that is then delivered to any identified vulnerable targets to spread the malware.
sentences.html: Once compilation is complete, the script then creates a batch file ‘update.sh’ which is used by the bot as a downloader that is then delivered to any identified vulnerable targets to spread the malware.

sentences.text: Figure 4. Generated `update.sh` file to spread EnemyBot on different architectures.
sentences.html: Figure 4. Generated `update.sh` file to spread EnemyBot on different architectures.

sentences.text: This is the main bot source code. Though it is missing the main exploitation function, it includes all other functionality of the malware and the attacks the bot supports by mixing the various botnet source codes as mentioned above (Mirai, Qbot, and Zbot) mainly Mirai and Qbot (see figure 5).
sentences.html: This is the main bot source code. Though it is missing the main exploitation function, it includes all other functionality of the malware and the attacks the bot supports by mixing the various botnet source codes as mentioned above (Mirai, Qbot, and Zbot) — mainly Mirai and Qbot (see figure 5).

sentences.text: Figure 5. EnemyBot source code.
sentences.html: Figure 5. EnemyBot source code.

sentences.text: This module is compiled and manually executed to encode / decode the malwares strings by the attacker to hide strings in binary. For that, the malware is using a simple swap table, in which each char is replaced with a corresponding char in the table (see in figure 6).
sentences.html: This module is compiled and manually executed to encode / decode the malware’s strings by the attacker to hide strings in binary. For that, the malware is using a simple swap table, in which each char is replaced with a corresponding char in the table (see in figure 6).

sentences.text: Figure 6. String decode.
sentences.html: Figure 6. String decode.

sentences.text: Figure 7 shows the command-and-control component (C&C) botnet controller. C&C will be executed on a dedicated machine that is controlled by the attacker. It can control and send commands to infected machines. (figure 7)
sentences.html: Figure 7 shows the command-and-control component (C&C) botnet controller. C&C will be executed on a dedicated machine that is controlled by the attacker. It can control and send commands to infected machines. (figure 7)

sentences.text: Figure 7. C&C component.
sentences.html: Figure 7. C&C component.

sentences.text: Most of EnemyBot functionality relates to the malwares spreading capabilities, as well as its ability to scan public-facing assets and look for vulnerable devices. However, the malware also has DDoS capabilities and can receive commands to download and execute new code (modules) from its operators that give the malware more functionality.
sentences.html: Most of EnemyBot functionality relates to the malware’s spreading capabilities, as well as its ability to scan public-facing assets and look for vulnerable devices. However, the malware also has DDoS capabilities and can receive commands to download and execute new code (modules) from its operators that give the malware more functionality.

sentences.text: In new variants of EnemyBot, the malware added a webscan function containing a total of 24 exploits to attack vulnerabilities of different devices and web servers (see figure 8).
sentences.html: In new variants of EnemyBot, the malware added a webscan function containing a total of 24 exploits to attack vulnerabilities of different devices and web servers (see figure 8).

sentences.text: Figure 8. EnemyBot calls for a new function webscan_xywz.
sentences.html: Figure 8. EnemyBot calls for a new function “webscan_xywz”.

sentences.text: To perform these functions, the malware randomly scans IP addresses and when it gets a response via SYN/ACK, EnemyBot then scans for vulnerabilities on the remote server by executing multiple exploits.
sentences.html: To perform these functions, the malware randomly scans IP addresses and when it gets a response via SYN/ACK, EnemyBot then scans for vulnerabilities on the remote server by executing multiple exploits.

sentences.text: The first exploit is for the Log4j vulnerability discovered last year as CVE-2021-44228 and CVE-2021-45046:
sentences.html: The first exploit is for the Log4j vulnerability discovered last year as CVE-2021-44228 and CVE-2021-45046:

sentences.text: Figure 9. Exploiting the Log4J vulnerability.
sentences.html: Figure 9. Exploiting the Log4J vulnerability.

sentences.text: The malware also can adopt new vulnerabilities within days of those vulnerabilities being discovered. Some examples are Razer Sila (April 2022) which was published without a CVE (see figure 10) and a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability impacting VMWare Workspace ONE with CVE-2022-22954 the same month (see figure 11).
sentences.html: The malware also can adopt new vulnerabilities within days of those vulnerabilities being discovered. Some examples are Razer Sila (April 2022) which was published without a CVE (see figure 10) and a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability impacting VMWare Workspace ONE with CVE-2022-22954 the same month (see figure 11).

sentences.text: Figure 10. Exploiting vulnerability in Razar Sila.
sentences.html: Figure 10. Exploiting vulnerability in Razar Sila.

sentences.text: Figure 11. Exploiting vulnerability in VMWare Workspace ONE.
sentences.html: Figure 11. Exploiting vulnerability in VMWare Workspace ONE.

sentences.text: EnemyBot has also begun targeting content management systems (e.g. Wordpress) by searching for vulnerabilities in various plugins, such as Video Synchro PDF (see figure 12).
sentences.html: EnemyBot has also begun targeting content management systems (e.g. Wordpress) by searching for vulnerabilities in various plugins, such as “Video Synchro PDF” (see figure 12).

sentences.text: Figure 12. EnemyBot targeting WordPress servers.
sentences.html: Figure 12. EnemyBot targeting WordPress servers.

sentences.text: In the example shown in figure 12, notice that the malware elevates a local file inclusion (LFI) vulnerability into a RCE by injecting malicious code into the /proc/self/environ. This method is not new and was described in 2009. The malware uses LFI to call environ and passes the shell command in the user agent http header.
sentences.html: In the example shown in figure 12, notice that the malware elevates a local file inclusion (LFI) vulnerability into a RCE by injecting malicious code into the ‘/proc/self/environ’. This method is not new and was described in 2009. The malware uses LFI to call ‘environ’ and passes the shell command in the user agent http header.

sentences.text: Another example of how the malware uses this method is shown in figure 13. In this example the malware is exploiting a vulnerability in DBltek GoIP.
sentences.html: Another example of how the malware uses this method is shown in figure 13. In this example the malware is exploiting a vulnerability in DBltek GoIP.

sentences.text: Figure 13. Executing shell command through LFI vulnerability in DBltek.
sentences.html: Figure 13. Executing shell command through LFI vulnerability in DBltek.

sentences.text: After infection, EnemyBot will wait for further commands from its C&C. However, in parallel it will also further propogate by scanning for additional vulnerable devices. Alien Labs has listed below the commands the bot can receive from its C&C (accurate as of the publishing of this article).
sentences.html: After infection, EnemyBot will wait for further commands from its C&C. However, in parallel it will also further propogate by scanning for additional vulnerable devices. Alien Labs has listed below the commands the bot can receive from its C&C (accurate as of the publishing of this article).

sentences.text: In case an Android device is connected through USB, or Android emulator running on the machine, EnemyBot will try to infect it by executing shell command. (figure 14)
sentences.html: In case an Android device is connected through USB, or Android emulator running on the machine, EnemyBot will try to infect it by executing shell command. (figure 14)

sentences.text: Figure 14. EnemyBot "adb_infect" function to attack Android devices.
sentences.html: Figure 14. EnemyBot "adb_infect" function to attack Android devices.

1.2: Ping to server, wait for command
1.5: Create a reverse shell on an infected machine.
1.11: Start TLS attack, start handshake without closing the socket.
1.14: Start/Stop scanner - scan and infect vulnerable devices.
1.17: Stop ongoing attacks. kill child processes
1.18: Start targeted attack on ARK: Survivor Evolved video game server.
1.19: Receive targets list from C&C and start DNS attack.

sentences.html:
Command

Action

SH

Execute shell command

PING

Ping to server, wait for command

LDSERVER

Change loader server for payload.

TCPON

Turn on sniffer.

RSHELL

Create a reverse shell on an infected machine.

TCPOFF

Turn off sniffer.

UDP

Start UDP flood attack.

TCP

Start TCP flood attack.

HTTP

Start HTTP flood attack.

HOLD

Start TCP connection flooder.

TLS

Start TLS attack, start handshake without closing the socket.

STD

Start non spoofed UDP flooder.

DNS

Start DNS flooder.

SCANNER ON | OFF

Start/Stop scanner - scan and infect vulnerable devices.

OVH

Start DDos attack on OVH.

BLACKNURSE

Start ICMP flooder.

STOP

Stop ongoing attacks. kill child processes

ARK

Start targeted attack on ARK: Survivor Evolved video game server.

ADNS

Receive targets list from C&C and start DNS attack.

ASSDP

Start SSDP flood attack.

sentences.text: Maintain minimal exposure to the Internet on Linux servers and IoT devices and use a properly configured firewall.<crlf>Enable automatic updates to ensure your software has the latest security updates.<crlf>Monitor network traffic, outbound port scans, and unreasonable bandwidth usage.
sentences.html:
1. Maintain minimal exposure to the Internet on Linux servers and IoT devices and use a properly configured firewall.
  2. Enable automatic updates to ensure your software has the latest security updates.
  3. Monitor network traffic, outbound port scans, and unreasonable bandwidth usage.

sentences.text: Keksecs EnemyBot appears to be just starting to spread, however due to the authors rapid updates, this botnet has the potential to become a major threat for IoT devices and web servers. The malware can quickly adopt one-day vulnerabilities (within days of a published proof of concept). This indicates that the Keksec group is well resourced and that the group has developed the malware to take advantage of vulnerabilities before they are patched, thus increasing the speed and scale at which it can spread.
sentences.html: Keksec’s EnemyBot appears to be just starting to spread, however due to the authors’ rapid updates, this botnet has the potential to become a major threat for IoT devices and web servers. The malware can quickly adopt one-day vulnerabilities (within days of a published proof of concept). This indicates that the Keksec group is well resourced and that the group has developed the malware to take advantage of vulnerabilities before they are patched, thus increasing the speed and scale at which it can spread.
